title: Welcome to My Research Portfolio
text:
Welcome to My Research Portfolio



Brandon Whitehead, shown in natureâ€™s laboratory.


Hello, Iâ€™m Brandon Whitehead, an [BLANK] fascinated by the dynamic nature of [BLANK].
My work with [BLANK] led to the discovery of [BLANK], [BLANK], and eventually, [BLANK] â€” [MORE EXPLANATION OF BLANK].
I am currently working on my PhD in Environmental Engineering Sciences at the University of Florida.
I have a Master of Science in Geography from Minnesota State University Mankato.
This site serves as a portfolio of my research, publications, and ongoing scientific interests.

title: research foci
text: My lifelong scientific interest lies in understanding how [BLANK] â€” and how [MORE GRANULAR EXPLANATION OF BLANK].

title: research foci
text:
Cytogenetics of Maize
Working with Zea mays, I developed techniques to visualize chromosomes under the microscope.
These methods enabled me to:
- Demonstrate crossing-over during meiosis.
- Identify the roles of telomeres and centromeres in maintaining chromosome stability.
- Track structural rearrangements in chromosomes across generations.

title: research foci
text:
Discovery of Transposable Elements
In the 1940s and 1950s, I discovered â€œjumping genesâ€, or transposons â€” mobile genetic elements that can change their position within the genome.
This finding revealed that the genome is not static, but instead dynamic and responsive to its environment.

title: research foci
text:
Later Research and Broader Impact
My later work extended into the cytogenetics and ethnobotany of South American maize races, integrating field studies with laboratory cytology.
These findings helped connect genetic variability with the evolutionary adaptation of maize to local environments.


â€œIf we only knew what we knowâ€¦ we would be astonished at the treasures contained in our knowledge.â€
â€“ Immanuel Kant, Vienna Logic (p.298)
